intro: Lappa tenella, commonly known as the lesser burr cucumber, is a member of the Apiaceae family. It is a biennial or short-lived perennial plant that typically grows up to 1 meter in height. The plant features hollow, ridged stems and large, pinnately lobed leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in umbels, and it produces distinctive, spiny fruits that are used as a natural seed dispersal mechanism. Lappa tenella is native to Europe and parts of Asia, and it is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides.
